channel.title: Optimization on Ricardo
channel.description: Recent content in Optimization on Ricardo

item.title: Optimization of a snow ball problem.
item.description: Snowball Rolling Suppose that we had a inclinated plane with a snowball in the higher zone. At the end onf that plane, there is a tree that requires a force of $25000N$ to get broke. The equations for the dynamics moves of the snowball are: \begin{equation} \Large\begin{array}{c} \frac{dm}{dt}=\beta K_0e^{-\beta t} \\ \frac{dr}{dt}=\frac{\beta K_0e^{-\beta t}}{4\pi\rho r^2} \\ \frac{dx}{dt}=v \\ \frac{dv}{dt}=-\frac{15\rho_aC_d}{56\rho}\frac{v^2}{r}-\frac{23v}{7r}\frac{\beta K_0e^{-\beta t}}{4\pi\rho r^2}+\frac{5}{7}gsin(\theta) \end{array} \end{equation} While the impact force is $F=\frac{K_E}{r}$, where $K_E$ is the kinetic energy.
